DOC.HEAD: Report: Thousands of Women Died from Illegal Abortions
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Romanian women died over the past few years from illegal or botched abortions because of deposed leader Nicolae Ceausescu's near-ban on the procedure, a report said. The report Thursday came after Romania's new interim government lifted Ceausescu's ban, which permitted few legal exceptions. Ceausescu instituted the abortion ban in 1966 to encourage procreation. He also banned the sale of contraceptives. Even before Ceausescu's ouster and execution, there had been reports in the official press of illegal abortions and doctors charging phenomenal sums for the service. ``The criminal act (the abortion restrictions) caused the death of thousands of women, many of them mothers of two to four children,'' the official Agerpres news agency said. Agerpres also quoted a leading medical official as saying ``a great many crippled babies were born'' because of inadequate maternity care, malnutrition and other complications. Under the 1966 law, abortions were permitted only for mothers who already had at least five children, in cases where childbirth could endanger the woman's life, when the pregnancy resulted from rape or incest, or when one of the parents suffered from serious disease that could result in birth defects. Mothers were given monthly allowances that varied according to the number of children they had. Still, the entire population was impoverished by the Ceausescu regime and for many, having children made their situation even worse. Dr. Bogdan Marinescu, head of the Giulesti Maternity House in Bucharest, said that over the last eight years nearly 1,400 women died from complications related to abortions in the capital alone, Agerpres said. The figure for Bucharest is apt to be even higher, Agerpres said, suggesting that hospitals and clinics attempted to hide the fact they had conducted abortions. ``Their number is by far bigger ... because, when in agony, many of them (pregnant mothers) were transferred to die in other medical departments,'' Agerpres said. It was not clear from the report how many of the purported deaths were a result of illegal abortions. Agerpres said Ceausescu's abortion ban was ``an aggression against millions of women, children and, ultimately families, the very national being.''
